p: With regard to Ca v3.3 research, we find only a single study where the team interfered with Ca v3.3 channel function using specific antisense oligonucleotides (ASOs) and demonstrated a corresponding mitigation of neuropathic pain behaviors in the chronic compression of the dorsal root ganglion (CCD) model [ 20]. We also find only a single study implicating T-type Ca 2+ channels in trigeminal neuropathic pain. In this study, the authors use an infraorbital nerve ligation model of trigeminal neuropathic pain and reveal that Cav3.1 channels are critically involved [ 21]. Therefore, the present study demonstrates a truly novel role for Ca v3.3 channels in a model of trigeminal neuropathic pain.
